course.subject: ECON
course.name: Mathematics for Economists
course.description: Exclusively for SB&M students.  This course provides students with mathematical tools frequently used in economic analysis. Topics include real numbers, single and multivariable functions, matrix algebra, multivariate calculus, convex analysis, and constrained and unconstrained optimization. Examples of economic analysis using these mathematical tools will be included.
course.prerequisites: MATH 1003 OR MATH 1012 OR MATH 1013 OR MATH 1020 OR MATH 1023; OR grade D or above in AL Applied Mathematics/Pure Mathematics
course.exclusions: MATH 2011, MATH 2023

reviews.author: Elkie Poon
reviews.comment_content:
The class covers a portion of multivariable calculus, including matrix operation, constrained and unconstrained optimization. Very hard for students with inadequate calculas background.

1. Sets (Mapping, Binary Relation)
2. Calculus I (Sequence, Convergence and limit, open and close sets)
3. Calculus II (Limit, Continuity, Derivative)
4. Linear Algebra (vectors, matrix, linear combination, linear independence, convex combination)
5. Calculus III (partial derivative, directional derivative, contour curve, implicit function)
6. Optimization (finding global and local maximizer, constrained optimization using Lagrangian and Kuhn-Tucker)
reviews.comment_teaching: Very passionate professor. However, the teaching is a bit boring and hard to follow, a lot of proving stuff. TA Wang Hei's is very helpful. He is willing to answer questions after class. His teaching is clear and much easier to follow. His response on email enquiries are quick.
reviews.comment_grading:
20% Homework
35% Midterm (4 multiple choices and 2 proving questions)
45% Final (6 long questions)

Very competitive course as most students are from ECOF and MAEC.
reviews.comment_workload:
7 problem sets with 6-9 questions on average.
You can get full marks on HW as long as you completed all questions regardless of accuracy.

No attendance taken. Lecture recordings are only available after the last lecture.

reviews.author: ANNNNDY
reviews.comment_content:
1. Sets (Mapping, Binary Relation)
2. Calculus I (Sequence, Convergence and limit, open and close sets)
3. Calculus II (Limit, Continuity, Derivative)
4. Linear Algebra (vectors, matrix, linear combination, linear independence, convex combination)
5. Calculus III (partial derivative, directional derivative, contour curve, implicit function)
6. Optimization (finding global and local maximizer, constrained optimization using Lagrangian and Kuhn-Tucker)
7. Additional content in the tutorial about Optimization (unconstrained optimization using Hessian Matrix)

Different from previous semesters, we focused a lot on proving stuff, but most proving questions in problem sets and exams could be solved through the definitions, so please make sure to have all complete definitions in your cheat sheet.
reviews.comment_teaching:
To be honest, I think the teaching is quite boring (mainly due to the fact that there is a lot of proving stuff...), but I could feel that Professor Wu had tried his best to make the in-class content more attractive.
Both Professor Wu and TA Wang Hei are willing to answer any questions you find during the whole course. (and please make sure to attend the tutorial session, especially for the optimization one)
reviews.comment_grading:
20% Homework
35% Midterm (4 multiple choices and 2 proving questions)
45% Final (6 long questions)

Midterm: Mean 69.69/100, SD 19.87
Final: Mean 80.55/120, SD 22.06

My Grade: Full score

Midterm is quite easy, but the final is much harder.
reviews.comment_workload:
7 problem sets with up to 10 questions
Graded by effort (if you complete every question and write something relevant to the question, you could get a full grade)

reviews.author: diiym
reviews.comment_content:
The first half is about Matrix
And the second half is about Optimisation ( with constraints and without constraints)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Quite good and clear
But somehow the pace is quite fast which makes it hard to catch up so I skipped all and watched the lecture video instead
reviews.comment_grading:
Really good
Below mean for midterm and most of the assignment but still got B
So don’t worry if you get a bad score in midterm
reviews.comment_workload:
Not too heavy
4assignments in total
And each assignment is released one week before the deadline

reviews.author: Isaac Yau
reviews.comment_content:
I think his content is the most difficult comparing to the past comments I see on the forum. It contains too many proofs and abstract concepts, I understand neither of those fully and doubt if all those concepts are practical. He loves to edit and edit the same chapter, so prepare to receive different versions so many times. It comes pretty annoying for me.

Chapters:
1. Sets
2. Calculus (I)
3. Calculus (II)
4. Linear algebra and convexity
5. Calculus (III)
6. Optimization
reviews.comment_teaching: He has a clean accent and interesting tone, so you might not fall asleep so fast comparing to other math professors. His teaching is ok but when it comes to difficult concepts, he spoke too fast; but when it comes to comparatively easier concepts, he stucked at a certain point for too long.  Sometimes, it’s hard to follow. However, he seems very enthusiastic to teach us, which is a plus side if you are eager to learn.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is absolutely good
I got around below 0.5 sd in midterm and below >1 sd in final (lower than LQ 10 marks) still got B-, big thanks to prof.

Midterm (35%)
Final (45%)
Homework (20%)
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is average, 7 problem sets for whole semester, each of them has around 6 to 9 long questions. However, as long as you do all of them, no matter you’re correct or not, you get full marks in Homework.

reviews.author: blank
reviews.comment_content:
Professor Wu teaches this course for the first time. The contents are quite different from the past.

1. Sets
2. Calculus I
3. Calculus II
4. Linear Algebra
5. Calculus III
6. Optimization

A lot of concepts!!! And anticipate that many lectures are proving something you already know in a way that you don't know.
Such as:
1. Proving A∪(B∪C) = A∪B∪C 🤨
2. Defining a closed interval [2,5]
3. Showing a strictly concaved function algebraically

The application part is covered only in optimization.
So from a practical perspective, you may not like it.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Passionate, Clear, Fluent English

Since lots of math course teachers are really bad at teaching, the way how Professor Wu can explain vague concepts clearly are something special 🤣
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework   20%
Midterm       35%
Final            45%

HW full
MT and Final: both a little little higher than 1 sd.

I don't like the mark distribution. No matter the difficulty, from 3-mins-question to 25-mins-question, they are weighted with the same marks in exams. Speechless🤣🤣🤣

A- at the end. (Fair)

P.S. Quite a competitive course, since most students are from ecof, which averages around 3.4-5. So knowing my friend scored about the mean and got a B (3), shows the professor does not increase the A range based on student quality.
reviews.comment_workload:
4 difficult problem sets (2-3 hours)
3 easy problem sets (1 hour)

At the end of the semester, TA told us the problem sets would be graded based on completeness.

So I guess the workload depends on how much effort you want to put in.

Since it's a four-cred course, not that bad.

reviews.author: Irissss
reviews.comment_content: The class covers a portion of multivariable calculus, including matrix operation, constrained and unconstrained optimization, and more. The content is not difficult to understand if you have taken some basic calculus before.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor gives very detailed explanations. She will provide extra examples during the lectures so make sure to take notes on those. Her lecture notes are clear and helpful for revisions. Overall she is super nice. The TA is also very nice, very willing to answer questions.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading consisted of 10% homework, 35% midterm, and 55% final. It's easy to get full marks on the homework as long as you put in some effort. The midterm and final are not difficult as long as you do all the homework by yourself and practice the past papers. So, not hard to get a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is very light. There are four homework assignments in total. The two before the midterm are fairly easy. The ones after the final take a bit more time (30min-1hr). Make sure to do these by yourself as the exams often have very similar questions to the homework.

reviews.author: Aprilfish
reviews.title: Math for economists
reviews.comment_content:
The foundations of economic theory are based on mathematical methods that have become
indispensable for a clear understanding of the current economic literature. This course introduces
students to a range of mathematical concepts and techniques that are necessary for undergraduate
studies in economics.  It is intended as a general introduction with a special emphasis on linear algebra
and optimization.  
Syllabus
1.  Economic models and Equilibrium analysis (Chapters 2 and 3)  
2.  Linear models and Matrix algebra (Chapters 4 and 5)
3.  Differentials and general function models (Chapters 6, 7, 8 and Page 383 - 389)
4.  Optimization – one variable (Chapter 9)
5.  Optimization -  More than one variable (Chapter 11)
6.  Constrained optimization (Chapter 12 and 13)
reviews.comment_teaching: A bit sleepy, but the content is good, introduces different ways of the derivation of the formula, help us to understand better, but somehow a bit massive.
reviews.comment_grading:
people in this course all came from ECOF, they are so hardworking, so the average is quite high, do not be upset if below mean, because the professor also understands this, so quite tolerant in grading.
mt below1.5 sd
final around mean
but still got b
Assessment
Homework assignment          10%  
Midterm Exam (Tuesday Oct 19 in-class)    35%
Final Exam (Date and venue TBD)      55%
reviews.comment_workload: one assignment/exercise each week, some of them are a bit difficult, but it is ok.

reviews.author: wanna
reviews.title: Great course and great professor!!
reviews.comment_content:
1.  Economic models and Equilibrium analysis
2.  Linear models and Matrix algebra
3.  Differentials and general function models
4.  Optimization – one variable
5.  Optimization -  More than one variable
6.  Constrained optimization
For business students, the difficulty is moderate and will not find it very challenging.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof.Zhou is very familiar with her lectures, and her logic of giving lecture is very clear. Her lecture notes are intuitive and have examples to explain various theories. She is also very welcome for us to ask her questions after class. She is so experienced that she knows where we are confused as soon as she sees our questions, and then she will explain clearly until we understand them.
Super nice professor!!!!
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework assignment   10%  
Midterm Exam   35%
Final Exam   55%
I think the professor gives grade based on absolute score, if your overall score can reach 90%+, which is quite easy if you work hard, you are guaranteed to get an A.  
Super good grade, especially in the case of ECOF students are very competitive.
reviews.comment_workload: Very very little workload!! It's like a two-credit course. Homework marked by TA should be handed every two weeks with few questions. Easy to handle!

reviews.author: Jedi Larmas
reviews.title: Great Course
reviews.comment_content:
1. Economic models and Equilibrium analysis
2. Linear models and Matrix algebra
3. Differentials and general function models
4. Optimization – One variable
5. Optimization - More than one variable
6. Constrained Optimization

The content is not that difficult in the first half. Although, the second half is a little bit more complex.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I like her teaching method as she explains different types of examples in every lecture which is quite useful as it sometimes appears in the exam.

She also sends weekly exercises that you don't have to submit for self-practice.

TA is a little bit useless as he only discusses the weekly exercises and assignments.
reviews.comment_grading:
Really good grading. The mean is really high which is expected as this is an ECOF specific course.

The exam format is the same as the assignments and practices.

Study all the practice questions, assignments, and past papers.

Grades:
Assignments: all above mean
Mid-term: 100
Final: Not published
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is light. Attendance is not graded so you can skip the lecture and watch the recording. Assignments are not that hard to achieve a perfect score.

reviews.author: icy
reviews.comment_content: I guess it's quite useful for future ECOF courses. Mainly focus on optimization. Contents are more difficult after midterm, they are also related, so make sure you understand the first few topics about matrix and multivariable differentiation.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is nice, very willing to help and answer students' questions. However, she tends to explain complicated stuff that are not needed for the course. She also pause a lot when speaking, it is sometimes difficult to understand what she wanted to express.
reviews.comment_grading: Not bad to me. Since it's a course for ECOF student, I expected it to be very competitive with bad grade. The mean for both midterm and final is quite high, around 8X. However, the B range is  wide, so getting a B is not difficult. But if you aim A range, work harder and carefully in your exams. Including Assignments (10%), Midterm (35%), and Final (55%),  I got around 95/100, an A+.
reviews.comment_workload: Only a few assignments, one midterm and one final. Workload is pretty light, but if you aim high in your exams, do some extra practices.

reviews.author: helpme
reviews.comment_content:
Contents are same every semester

Topic 1: Economic Models and Equilibrium Analysis
Topic 2: Linear Models and Matrix Algebra
Topic 3: Differentials and General Function Models
Topic 4: Optimisation of Single Variable Objective Functions
Topic 5: Unconstrained Optimisation
Topic 6: Constrained Optimisation

Topic 5 and 6 would be more applicable to the field of economics, so it becomes more interesting by then (but not enjoyable)
reviews.comment_teaching:
I like the prof, she is nice and knowledgable. However, I honestly don't think that her teaching method fits with those who are not confident with mathematics.

When she delivers her lecture, she often provides some "fun" tips by bringing in the Masters level contents, and that brings some students - who were struggling to even follow the class contents - into pure terror.

I think that she should deliver her lectures by providing some easier example questions (so that we can follow) at first and then move to some weird looking economic application questions so that we can at least undetstand what the hell is going on
reviews.comment_grading:
Its grading is not quite bad compared with other lectures. Both my midterm final were almost near the mean score, and ended up receiving a letter grade of B.

We are in UST, so B for a mean is really not a bad thing. I am rather thankful for what I received.

Not sure what driving factors are there, but the mean is quite high given that its a mathematics course. What kind of a mathematics course would have a mean of 80s in its midterm and finals?
reviews.comment_workload:
It solely depends on how sturdy your mathematical background is.

The workload is not that bad as it requires only 4 graded assignments and no projects or whatever. However, if you are not really good at math (like me) you would need to invest quite a lot of time revising for the content itself. But if you are already good at math and you just want to chill, you are free to chill, just do well on your exams.

reviews.author: Sohi
reviews.comment_content:
1. EconomicmodelsandEquilibriumanalysis(Chapters2and3)
2. Linear models and Matrix algebra (Chapters 4 and 5)
3. Differentialsandgeneralfunctionmodels (Chapters6, 7, 8 and Page383-389)
4. Optimisation - one variable (Chapter9)
5. Optimisation - More than one variable (Chapter 11)
6. Constrained optimisation (Chapter 12 and 13)
The content is easy. If you understand the content, it is easy to get high marks.
reviews.comment_teaching: Her teaching is clear and easy to understand. But the tutorial didn’t help as a math course.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not as good as I thought. The competition is fierce, just try to be as accurate as you can. Don’t make any mistake.
For your information, the mean of mid term:85. The mean of final exam:83.
Around mean(or even slightly below) may get a B.
reviews.comment_workload: 4assignments only. No attendance required.

reviews.author: Earline
reviews.comment_content:
The materials before midterm are similar to MATH1013. After midterm content are more specified for economics students.
Topic 1: Economic Models and Equilibrium Analysis
Topic 2: Linear Models and Matrix Algebra
Topic 3: Differentials and General Function Models
Topic 4: Optimisation of Single Variable Objective Functions
Topic 5: Unconstrained Optimisation
Topic 6: Constrained Optimisation
reviews.comment_teaching: Her teaching is general, the materials she used are all in the powerpoint. However, the way she explains things are confusing. It is more helpful to learn from the TA.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 35%
Final 55%
Homework 10%
Good grading! The mean for midterm was high because the students are very competitive but don't worry if you got below mean, it was relatively harder than final so you can boost your grade if you study hard for the final.
reviews.comment_workload: Low workload, no attendance. There are assignments, some you need to hand in, some don't. Very chill

reviews.author: vino
reviews.comment_content:
1. EconomicmodelsandEquilibriumanalysis(Chapters2and3)
2. Linear models and Matrix algebra (Chapters 4 and 5)
3. Differentialsandgeneralfunctionmodels (Chapters6, 7, 8 and Page383-389)
4. Optimisation - one variable (Chapter9)
5. Optimisation - More than one variable (Chapter 11)
6. Constrained optimisation (Chapter 12 and 13)

Content isn't hard. It provides solid math fundamentals for ECOF students to study future ECON courses
reviews.comment_teaching:
She tends to explain complicated examples that won't be tested.

She rushes too much and students with weak math background found it difficult to catch up. It's better to ask TA instead of the professor when you encountered problems.
reviews.comment_grading: Good grading since it is a course designed for ECOF students, the grading won't be bad anyways.
reviews.comment_workload: It depends. Weekly assignment is a must. But if you are trying to master the concepts, u gotta work extra hard and put a lot of effort in doing supplementary exercises.

reviews.author: MoLau
reviews.comment_content: This course cover lots of maths which will be used in later ECON courses, so it is pretty important for ECOF or ECON major student
reviews.comment_teaching: basically I learn all topics myself. Professor is not that helpful if not totally useless
reviews.comment_grading:
Very good grade
Almost give up final ( below mean ) still get B
reviews.comment_workload: It depends. If you want to understand all topics you have to spend a lot of time. Professor is not that good at explain concepts so lectures do not help much.  Thus sometimes homework can spend you some time.

reviews.author: carol lam
reviews.title: Very good grading
reviews.comment_content:
Most important is the optimization
When you can solve optimization between several variables,you must get a B.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Answer your questions patiently
Explain the concepts by using several examples
Very good prof
reviews.comment_grading:
Very good!!!!!!!
If you are below mean,don't worry !!!!!
You can still in B range
reviews.comment_workload:
Low workload,No attendance
Homework for every chapters
Homework is good for your understanding
If you can solve problems in the problem set,you will be okay in the exams
One midterm and one final
However the final accounts 55% towards your grading

reviews.author: komasn
reviews.title: Good Grade
reviews.comment_content: Content is hard and cover many topics(e.g matrix, partial derivatives)
reviews.comment_teaching: Quite boring but straightforward. However, sometimes hard to follow. Because she seems like falling into her world and students can't follow or know what she was doing
reviews.comment_grading:
Very good grade. Just follow pastpaper. Most of the questions are same as the previous years but a change in numbers. Even in my year, some questions have been changed to a new one, still have a good grade.
Mid term: most people get 9x/100, some are 100/100.
reviews.comment_workload: Zero workload. Homework is easy and you can find the answer in lecture notes.

reviews.author: nicoleee
reviews.comment_content: the content is not difficult, with medium math background.
reviews.comment_teaching:
the teaching is general.
the professor did interact with students and make sure most of the students in class understand well.
But sometimes she complicates the explanation process, going too deep to some advance topics that makes me more difficult to understand lol...
reviews.comment_grading:
very good grading
content is easy but the competition is fierce as fellows are working hard
below mean in midterm and final but got a B
reviews.comment_workload: not much work to do at all, assignments were posted for every topic, but not all of them are required to be handed in. So you got enough exercise to work on if you want.

reviews.author: JULESSS
reviews.comment_content: As the course name says, the course teaches basic Mathematics required for Economics.The subjects covered vary from basic matrices to calculus.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor teaches based on the powerpoint material she has made. As long as you can follow her material, you will be able to do well on the assessments. As the instructor says in class, the textbook isn't that useful - there is no additional reading required for the course.
reviews.comment_grading:
This one of the courses with easy grading.
The course is graded on 1 midterm and 1 final exam.
The exam format and difficulty is exactly like the sample questions she hands out before exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are assignment/homework to hand in to TA on average once every 2 weeks.
There is no attendance.
The workload is quite light.

reviews.author: Kenny Li
reviews.title: Mathematics for Economists
reviews.comment_content: The content is simple to most students with medium mathematics background. However, it is very useful (according to professor).
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor will strictly follow the lecture notes, if you could understand the lecture notes beforehand, which is not difficult to most students, you can just skip the lesson with no worries.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is really good. The exams are straightforward that all the questions are pretty similar to the assignment and the examples of the lecture notes. If you could get over 85% in final, which is not difficult if you deal with the numbers carefully, you will be guaranteed to get an A.
reviews.comment_workload: There is almost no workload in this course because you will only be assessed in assignment, midterm and final exam. There is no attendance required in both lecture and tutorial and since the material covered in this course is quite simple, you don’t need to do much review after the lecture or even before the exam. Overall, you can easily get through this course without making much effort.

reviews.author: luobei
reviews.title: super nice prof and helpful TA
reviews.comment_content:
1. Sets (Mapping, Binary Relation)
2. Calculus I (Sequence, Convergence and limit, open and close sets)
3. Calculus II (Limit, Continuity, Derivative)
4. Linear Algebra (vectors, matrix, linear combination, linear independence, convex combination)
5. Calculus III (partial derivative, directional derivative, contour curve, implicit function)
6. Optimization (finding global and local maximizer, constrained optimization using Lagrangian and Kuhn-Tucker)
7. Additional content in the tutorial about Optimization (unconstrained optimization using Hessian Matrix)

positive: easy to follow, easy exams
negative: you will not learn many new things given it is a 4 credits course
reviews.comment_teaching:
very clear and patient, sometimes may sound verbose.
focus more on the proving and concept
he is willing to reply to your questions after class, so if you have any questions, go and ask him
he is an easy-going guy after class
reviews.comment_grading:
20% Homework
35% Midterm (4 multiple choices and 2 proving questions)
45% Final (6 long questions)

Midterm: Mean 69.69/100, SD 19.87
Final: Mean 80.55/120, SD 22.06

easy to get good grades as long as you followed the lecture and finished the assignments
reviews.comment_workload:
not a difficult course so it won't take you much time

both midterm and final exams were open book exams so you can print all the lecture PPT which were enough for the exam.

his assignments are kind of challenging. (don't worry, the questions in the exams are not that hard. most are basic questions you will see in the assignments or on the slides) You can search online or discuss with each other. The answer will be uploaded to canvas soon after the deadline. As long as you upload the assignment, you will get full marks for the 20%homework.

no attendance. the recordings will be uploaded after the last lecture

reviews.author: Dioxider
reviews.title: 还是很不错的，教授人贼好，又一个我的ust野爹
reviews.comment_content:
内容前半部分是一些数理证明 后半部分是微积分和矩阵。前半部分难度很大，后半部分其实很简单。我的评价是前面的内容实用性感觉实在不强，只是给了你在数学上和别人装逼的一些资本（。
大家上完前半学期别灰心，曙光在后面。
但是抽象思维一定要好，期末六道大题，有两道思维难度还很大，但assignment要是可以独立解90%以上也没太大问题。
reviews.comment_teaching:
教的不错，没有奇怪的口音，技术很好
深入浅出 基本上算是本学期最佳教授
reviews.comment_grading:
overall 90+ 最后拿的A
mideterm很简单，听课闭眼过。但是final有一定难度
Homework (20%), midterm exam (35%), final exam (45%)
感觉还是不错的，但是sd很大 期中期末sd都20+。
极度不建议抽象思维差的同学上这门课，前面A range很卷。
reviews.comment_workload:
数学好的上课玩手机
数学差的上课很累很累
再说一遍 这个课个体差距极大，一定要根据自己数学情况去take，不能因为好grade盲目上
